YNWA.

story:
2020 was a trying year for most, for lots of different reasons. I've set up this JustGiving page in tribute to my wonderful dad, who sadly lost his life after a tragic accident.

Dominic was hit by a car when he was out cycling on Sunday 25th October 2020 and was sent home from hospital to recuperate. After a period of improvement, he suffered a massive internal bleed on Monday 16th November 2020 and died very quickly, at home. Dominic will be loved and missed forever by all his family, friends and work colleagues alike.

Dad was a great supporter of the BHF and the work they did was very close to his heart (excuse the pun..). My Dad also absolutely LOVED cycling. It was his biggest passion in life, aside from his family. His AMAZING colleagues at Microsoft have started a fundraising initiative in his name and we would love if his family & friends and any avid cycling fans would join us in raising money for this fantastic charity in his name. 

Next time you go for a bike ride (or walk/run if you don't cycle like me..), we are asking that you upload a picture with the hashtag #RideWithDom , donate some dollar (pennies or pounds, it all adds up!) and share the page with your friends. It would be amazing to see the hashtag flooded with pictures of people getting outdoors in this awful time and thinking of a truly brilliant man. 

Thank you for all of your support so far, the family have been truly uplifted in this awful time by everyone's assistance and messages of love. 

Now, let's get fundraising! #RideWithDom

Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
First a Word From the British Heart Foundation: 

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

I would also like to add that I already have had some problems with my heart so I feel especially qualified to do this challenge. My Grandpa had a Heart Attack in Front Of My Grandma and it was a real shock to us all as she was the one who was already very sick with Parkinson’s, Alzheimer’s and mobility problems. I am doing this for their memory, my Grandpa gave his all to Love her, taking her out of the home she was in because they were always so very much in love. I like to think that they know I am doing it for them and hope to make them proud even though we have now lost them both. I believe my Grandma died 6 months later from a broken heart 💔 She even told her Carers, the day she died that Jack had come for her! It was just the sort of thing he would have done for her, anything and everything. I Love Chocolate and have a very sweet tooth so I am giving them up for March, please open your hearts and purses to support me, every penny helps ❤️ Thanks in Advance, Wendy.

story:
In the UK today, almost two million people are living with sight loss and of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone. Many suffer from depression and struggle with feelings of isolation.

Guide Dogs is here to help solve this problem. We provide individual support that overcomes the emotional and physical challenges faced by people living with sight loss.

We work for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life. We work for a world where blind people no longer feel invisible, where the quality of their eye sight is genuinely the only difference between them and the rest of society.

A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling your needs and dreams. A world where being blind or partially sighted isn't what defines you.

In May 2021, we will be taking on the huge challenge of running the London Landmarks Half Marathon. The last year has been an unprecedented and incredibly challenging year for the charity sector and the impact of Covid-19 has meant many charities are now struggling to raise the vital income they need to survive. Your support this year is more important than ever so thank you so much in advance for donating whatever you can. It really will make a massive difference.

story:
In April last year my mum, Pippa Stone, passed away. Out of the blue she’d had a seizure, which we learned later had been caused by an aggressive brain tumour, and she died just 18 days later. Mum had just turned 60, had retired a week before her diagnosis and she and dad had been planning to travel the world. It was a devastating shock for all who loved her. When we were told that she had weeks to live, her response was ‘it is what it is’, and her strength has carried me through the months since and inspired me to live with the same courage that she taught me. 

I want to do something positive in her memory so, myself and my partner, Lauren, are going to walk the Jurassic Coast to raise money for a charity close to both of our hearts: Cancer Research UK. To be able to raise vital funds for research and to support this incredible charity, which has been struggling through the pandemic, would be truly heartening to us. Lauren, who will be walking alongside and fundraising with me to reach our target, also sadly lost her father to a brain tumor. Together we are determined to try to make a difference. 

Our route for our challenge is from Exmouth in Devon to Swanage in Dorset, and we will don our walking boots from the 13th to the 19th of March 2021. Lauren and I are organising this sponsored trek on our own, just us, our backpacks and several packed lunches. The length of this walk is just over 100 miles and with our goal to complete the walk in 7 days we will be covering as many as 20 miles a day, come rain or shine. This is guaranteed to be a shock in comparison to the 100 daily steps we are currently taking during lockdown … from the sofa to the fridge, and back again – but we’re determined to succeed.

We understand how tough a time this is to encourage charitable donations, but Cancer Research UK has experienced a huge drop in funding during this time and their work has been slowed by the impact of Covid-19. It would mean so much to us to be able to contribute to what this great organisation does. Any donation, big or small, or even a share of this page, will help. Please spread the word to help us go above and beyond our fundraising target!

My mum would have been 61 on March 21st and Lauren’s dad 57 on March 4th, so this month holds a lot of emotional weight for us both. And so, we want to stomp 100 miles, whatever the weather, each step sparing a thought for those who have been affected by this awful illness. 

Let’s raise as much as we possibly can and fight back against cancer. Make the blisters worth it! Your support would mean the world.

With love

Josie & Lauren

We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

charity.name: Marie Curie
charity.registrationNumber: 207994 (England & Wales) and SC038731 (Scotland)
story:
Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. 
We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

story:
The Marie Curie Bradford Hospice supports people living with a terminal illness and those closest to them to live as well as possible. The Hospice is often very different from what people expect it is a warm, friendly space with beautiful gardens, delicious home-cooked food and personalised care. Every person is treated as an individual and helped to reach their goals and fulfil their wishes. A team of nurses, doctors, social workers, physiotherapists, chaplains, bereavement counsellors and pharmacists work together, putting every person at the centre of their care. Throughout Covid-19 Bradford Hospice teams have been working around the clock to continue supporting local people. Death, dying and bereavement is at the forefront of peoples minds and Marie Curie knows what a difference the right care at the end of life can make. They cant do any of this without your support. Thank you for your generous donation which supports the Bradford Hospice and Marie Curie care.

My mother was treated with respect, care and love and her symptoms were well controlled while cared for in the Bradford Hospice.  At present, due to the Covid restrictions, it is very difficult for the Hospice to raise vital money to maintain essential services.  Any contributions will make a difference.  Thank you..

story:
Whitby RNLI would like to send their condolences in memory of well-loved fundraiser Phil Jones who has sadly passed away. 

A Husband, dad and grandad, Morris Dancer, Shantyman and great supporter of the RNLI, Phil died peacefully aged 69 in Malton Hospital after a short illness.

He will be laid to rest in his red lifeboat sweatshirt at a private burial in Kirkbymoorside churchyard on Friday 8 January. His cortege will pass the George and Dragon and the King's Head just after 1.45pm.

Instead of flowers, the family have requested donations to Whitby Lifeboat via this JustGiving page.

A memorial service and wake will be held once Covid-19 restrictions are lifted.

story:
The RNLI Bembridge Station and branch are supporting lifeboats in the South East that protect hundreds of communities through their 24-hour search and rescue service.

Our Crews rely on the safest, most reliable lifeboats and modern stations to launch from. From the stunning Dorset, Sussex and Kent coastlines to the unpredictable tidal Thames, our favourite places in the South east are enjoyed by millions of people from across the country every year. But the water remains an unpredictable environment that can catch people out. People will always need our help and we will always be there to answer that call.

The RNLI relies on donations from you the public to continue saving lives at sea and on the Thames. Your donation will help keep us afloat in 2021 and support saving lives for years to come.

Thank you for your support.

story:
The situation in Yemen at the moment is an absolute disgrace to humanity. Horrific. Yet, insanely, it gets very little attention in the media despite it being one of the worst humanitarian crises in recent memory.

After five years of conflict, most of the population in Yemen needs humanitarian assistance. They have a lack of basic healthcare, severe food shortages and limited clean water. CARE is focused on helping the most vulnerable people, through distributing food to families in need, and cash vouchers so that families can purchase for themselves the food they need.Over a year of fighting and fuel shortages has destroyed water pipes and water pumping facilities, so CARE is rehabilitating water sources and providing water tanks so women and children can get safe drinking water without having to travel long distances.CARE is also providing hygiene kits, paying special attention to womens and children's needs.Thank you for reading. For more information please visit the dedicated Yemen Crisis page on CARE's website: www.careinternational.org.uk/emergencies/yemen-crisis
